Outlines, bulleted lists, or diagrams alone are not acceptable and will not be scored.Enolase is an enzyme that catalyzes one reaction in glycolysis in all organisms that carry out this process. The amino acid sequence of enolase is similar but not identical in the organisms. Researchers purified enolase from Saccharomyces cerevisiae, a single-celled eukaryotic yeast that grows best at <math alttext="37 degrees Celsius" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>37</mtext><mi>°</mi><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, and from Chloroflexus aurantiacus, a bacterium that grows best at the much higher temperature of <math alttext="55 degrees Celsius" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>55</mtext><mi>°</mi><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. The researchers compared the activity of purified enolase from the two organisms by measuring the rate of the reaction in the presence of varying concentrations of substrate and a constant amount of each enzyme at both <math alttext="37 degrees Celsius" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>37</mtext><mi>°</mi><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="55 degrees Celsius" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>55</mtext><mi>°</mi><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.(a) Depending on the organism, the optimal <math alttext="p H" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>pH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> for enolase to catalyze its reaction is between <math alttext="6.5" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>6.5</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="8.0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>8.0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. Describe how a <math alttext="p H" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>pH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> below or above this range is likely to affect enolase and its catalytic ability.
